reviewText: I'm not the type to really enjoy a JRPG, but there are a few that capture my attention. Pier Solar and the Great Architects is defintiely one of those games. I previously owned only on my Sega Genesis and I absolutely loved it. The visual appeal, the great music, and the immersive story. The turned-based combat is also pretty refined compared to others in it's genre. Pier Solar HD is essentially the same game but with better visuals, a remastered soundtrack, and beautiful backgrounds that bring the world to life. To cut to the chase, if you like JRPGs or are looking for an experience, check out Pier Solar HD. If you enjoyed Chrono Trigger, Earthbound, or Final Fanstasy VI, you will love Pier Solar.

reviewText: THIS GAME IS AMAZING, Seriously, If you've ever played the Megadrive release you'd know that, I'm playing this baby on my Arch Linux system. Who says us linux users don't love games? I've been playing this release so far and am loving the updated music (Which was available on the megadrive release if you had the CD addon) and the updated Graphics. They definitely add to the game, the combat system is tried-but-true with updated features, what else can I say about this game? BUY IT RIGHT NOW, BUY THE DREAMCAST RELEASE. BUY IT. 10/10 would buy again.

reviewText: This game's a pretty decent old-school RPG. Characters are fun, environments are pretty, the new music is good (some of the old stuff is pretty rough, as are some of the sound effects). A few UI choices are a little wonky (like how you cast healing spells), but you get used to them pretty quick, though I did keep noticing my little gripes. All and all, pretty fun, I enjoy it. If it's on sale, give it a shot.\n\nThough there is a timing/platforming section at the magic school which I hate, hate, hate. For that infurating section alone, this game might end up burning in video game hell. You'll get past it after a stressful hour or two, though.

reviewText:
Always wished there were more RPGs on the Genesis.  I'm glad the guys at WaterMelon shared that opinion so strongly that they made their own.  While the game suffered through development hell (the original Genesis version from my understanding... as well as this HD version which I feel like I waited a year after the scheduled release date to check out), it finally came.  It managed to captivate me in the way RPGs did in my youth.  I honestly didn't think I was going to enjoy it that much.

A few notes:
- Battles are reminiscent of Lunar both in the way of style and challenge.  Areas can seem gimmicky and lack variety in fights up until a boss or change of region, however.
- Sound is wonderful and fitting of the game's environments and mood.  Perfectly done in Genesis style.  The HD music is even better.
- The options to swap between original graphics and HD, as well as original and HD sound are nice.
- Without listing all the reasons, I feel the game has some replay value (I can see 1 or 2 more playthoughs in the future for mehself).  Obviously I'm not looking at it with nostalgia goggles either.
- The characters are likeable, which is good due to the fact you'll be spending quite a few hours with them.

Overall, I'd give it an 8 out of 10.  There's not too many great RPGs on the Genesis, so this game is  welcomed by me.  I'd even go as far as to place it at my number three spot of favorite Genesis RPGs, falling short of only Phantasy Star IV and Shining Force II.  If you're a fan of those titles and also Lunar, then definitely try to pick it up if ya see it on sale, and give it a shot.

Happy Gaming, friends!!
voteText: 17 of 19 people (89%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
So I held off on reviewing this game until I was completely done with it so I could give a fair and proper judgement, this review is long and will cover mostly things I can't stand about the game. As a JRPG and RPG fanatic in general, I just can't justify telling people to go out and purchase or bother wasting their time playing this game because frankly, you're not missing out on anything at all.

I'm not going to spoil any plot points in this review, but I will be spoiling elements of the game play and areas so you'll understand my frustrations.

Plot
It's a fairly standard JRPG plot, it doesn't do anything remotely new or interesting and brings nothing to the table. Same old tired cliches you've seen before but I suppose they were just trying to recreate that nostalgia and archetype's from the golden years of gaming. The three mains are likable enough but the rest of the cast is just kind of there and I didn't really connect with their personalities or designs. The villains are standard garbage stereotypes, not even going to bother getting in to it... They rip off just about every Final Fantasy game in existance, which is just another testament to how unoriginal and uninspired it is.

World Map / Game Structure / Pacing
This game's structure and pacing is a bit of an oddity as it just decides to switch up the formula about half way through. For the first half of the game you basically choose destinations by pressing left or right on the d-pad and it will cycle through the available locales. At about the half way mark the developers just decided to start linking all the dungeons and towns together so it all becomes one giant cluster♥♥♥♥ of a maze.

So you'll get a formula of Town - Dungeon - Side Town - Dungeon - Main Town - Side Dungeon Under Town - Warp to an entirely unrelated area with no way of going back - rinse and repeat for the rest of the game.

It becomes rather tiresome at the 90% mark when you have to walk through previously explored area's just so you can backtrack to pick up items you couldn't access before. There is a warp device given to you late in the game but it doesn't really help, it just allows you access to the previous chapters" of the game that all seem to be separated by islands that are no longer linked together and must be accessed separately.

The worst feature of the warp device is that you can't just call upon it whenever you feel like
date:
like the airship from Final Fantasy or the Flamme Drum from Secret of Mana... No you actually have to walk ALL the way back to the device and touch it on some arbitrarily placed square on one of the sides of it (it's different in each area) in order to continue on with the game.

This is what I'm talking about when I say the game requires A LOT of polish... Something this important shouldn't be overlooked... It's an essential part of the gameplay and it's confusing and obnoxious as hell to figure out due to lazy programming.

Completionist's Nightmare / Cryptic Secrets / Poor NPC placement
If you're one of those people who enjoy getting 100% completion rates in RPG's... just forget it. There isn't a solid guide on the web because this game is such a sleeper cult game... I can't even use the word "hit" in there because I don't even think it reached those kinds of sales numbers.

Either way
recommended: all the secrets in this game are cryptic and obnoxious
hoursPlayed: invisible walls with zero tells... just start walking in to everything and hope you find something. There are treasure chests in unreachable places that MUST be opened with a spell from a distance... I found this was a major design flaw because some chests I didn't even bother walking to
voteText: I would just open them through walls. I found this to be incredibly lame and lazy.\n\nThere are hidden dungeons and items
helpfulPercent: most of which are missable and you can never return to. There are side quests hidden all over the place as well and some won't even open up until certain points in the plot which can be rather annoying... You could talk to everyone in the city but after you trigger a main plot event
votesHelpful:
the people you talked to could have a quest for you to embark on but you've missed it under the assumption those characters were just background objects filling the cities.

There's also a side quest and a main quest in this game where they place an important NPC against the same coloured backdrop so it's nearly impossible to spot it unless you literally stop in your tracks and scan the area with your eyes... It's probably because of how quickly the game moves when your characters are running... The Genesis was notorious for creating blurred backgrounds due to it's "superior blast processing" >.< LOL.... what a joke.

Just be warned that you'll most likely never find everything in the game
votesTotal:
I know I missed a dungeon and I couldn't return back to it because they give you a single opportunity to access it. I missed a side quest some where as well... and quite possibly a shop... even though I was incredibly thorough.

Glitched achievements
I found all the master keys
votesFunny: never got the achievement for doing so... even though I opened all 8 treasure chests with the ultimate gear. This leads me to believe the "Shop-a-Holic" achievement is also glitched
column16:
more polish required.

Battle System / Battle Pacing
Terrible... just a terrible battle system. You have to "charge up" like Goku from DBZ so your characters can multiply their pitiful damage output and you have to have a full "gather" meter to use some of the best spells. If you so much as get hit before your turn comes up
column17: you lose 1 gather and the spell is rendered ineffective. Your character will then miss their turn and spin around like a jack ♥♥♥ as to symbolize that they're confused. AWFUL DESIGN.\n\nThere's still hope though
column18: you can give away your gather to other party members to help them use their OP attacks but at the cost of missing another characters turn for that round and what's worse
column19: it's all or nothing... You can't just give away 1 or 2 gather... NOPE
column20: you have to give away ALL of it...\n\nSo for example
column21: a character requires 5 gather to use an ultimate special attack but the character only has 4
column22: you can then request gather from another party member. However in the likely event that the member that you're requesting from has 5 gather... well you then proceed to steal all of it instead of just using some basic math... because apparently in this game 5 - 1 = 0.   :/    DUMB.\n\nYou'll get in to fights every 15 steps... Considering every dungeon in this game is a convoluted maze of eye tricks and illusionary walls
column23: it's just an awful and frustrating mix. There's a spell that helps you avoid fights but it's literally only for about 45 steps and BAM
column24: another fight. This means every 40 or so steps you have to recast the spell and watch some obnoxiously slow spell animation taking place... What ever happened to a symbol appearing next to your character's portrait to show you have some kind of spell effect active? Like come on...\n\nFor a game made for a system with "blast processing" it's the slowest and most annoyingly paced JRPG I've ever played in my life... I think I'd rather play Final Fantasy Anothology on the PSX with the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ menu load times than have to deal with how this game's mechanics work. I'm not even going to talk about that menu that shows up every round of battle... oh wait
column25:
I just did... jesus man.

Final Thoughts
It's a failed attempted at bringing a game as epic as Final Fantasy VI to the Sega Genesis platform and it just misses the mark on every single attempt... The game had a cool concept and appealing artwork but it ends there... Genesis was never a system for RPG's and I can see why now... No developer could smooth out all the kinks with menus and game structure... This game is a prime example of why all the big RPG developers chose the SNES."

reviewText:
I love classic games and JRPGs in general.  I had been looking forward to playing Pier Solar ever since I first heard about the game, so I was glad to see a digital version available for purchase on Steam.  The music and art are both excellent, but everything else about this game is horrible.  It's not a matter of taste or me just not liking the style---I'll give anything the benefit of the doubt and I would continue to do so for Pier Solar, but I just can't go on.

Here's what's wrong with the game:
1.  The game freezes often.
2.  There are input problems when playing with a controller.  The developer suggested fix did nothing to help.
3.  The combat system is awful and battle times can be measured in minutes (usually 2 or 3 for every battle).
4.  The design of the maps is terrible.  Everything--including the towns--is like a maze.
5.  Often, there are concealed paths or platforms behind what is visible to you on the screen.
6.  The story moves at such a glacial pace that at 6 hours in, I still don't know what it is about.
7.  Nothing in the game seems to fit together stylistically.  There is a real lack of cohesion and everything feels off.

I didn't believe the negative reviews when I read them, because most of the points sounded minor on paper.  They really aren't.  Please learn from my mistake and avoid wasting your money on this game.  It is both frustrating and lifeless.  If you want to play a good classic game on the Sega Genesis (which is what Pier Solar was originally designed for), check out Phantasy Star IV.  If you want a unique JRPG that is a bit more modern, try The Legend of Heroes:  Trails in the Sky.

reviewText:
WaterMelon have simply outdone themselves.
Pier Solar is a fantastic game, and I've never liked nor finished a JRPG before. This changes it all, it makes me wish I had a SEGA MegaDrive just to play this new HD+ remake on. Written Impression below

http://youtu.be/55aWE-ZNW54

It looks, sounds, and plays wonderfully. The story started off rather strangely, and didn't grip me at first, due to it being a simple, kids need to save a father.
During that part of the game, you discover ancient runes, a new language, and magic happens. Changing everything from there on you finally start your grand adventure, and venture into the world.

I really enjoy the game, and having the options to play with the original graphics and sound track is also a very nice touch.

I would happily recommend the game to fans of RPG, and particularly JRPGs like Chronotrigger and the first Final Fantasy games

reviewText:
I wanted to like this game; I'm a big fan of JRPGs from the 16bit era. I gave it 5 hours and man what a tedious 5 hours of gameplay that was.

The combat system just doesn't do it for me. Some of your attacks cannot shoot flying enemies, which sounds cool, but it makes combat slow and annoying. Have flying mobs but only 1/5 of your party can shoot up? Go ahead and cast a spell at it... after wasting a turn gathering so you can cast a spell. No thanks. It could have been so much better with a priority auto selection of ground mobs.

There were also too many times where I just didn't know where to go. So many paths are obscured and hidden behind things that make the 'puzzle' part of the game more like a 'HAHA ♥♥♥♥ you' from the level designer.

reviewText:
Before writing this review, I should make it known that the version I am currently playing is the Wii U version.

So this is also a review in progress, so to speak.

Pier Solar is essentially a mixed bag. It's a decent story with some awkward writing here and there, and it has a really lovely tileset (in most places) with atrocious layout. One of my issues with this game is some dungeons or towns just aren't straight forward enough. They feel to... maze-y. Not that that's a bad thing, it's just in most towns, when you barely know where your going, that causes problems. It doesn't help that in some cases, it's hard to tell where you can and can't walk. As I said though, the tile sets themselves are lovely.

Which brings us to another point. The tilesets are nice looking. the enhanced rendered visuals... not so much. The rendered version makes the background look like they were made in photoshop or illustrator, which would not be bad, had the characters themselves matched visually. But to be honest, it's sometimes harder to tell whats going on in the visuals with the rendered backgrounds. With the pixel art, it just pops out more.

Story as I said isn't bad. I won't say anything on it, but I will say that some instances feel just as a matter of fact. One character joins because he/she just feels bad for you. Come on. And it's delivery (as far as I am anyway) just doesn't surprise. It's all extremely predictable.

The battles take forever... There is a system where you can charge up your energy to make attacks more powerful, but that takes up one full turn, and it opens you up to enemy attack. The saving grace is you can share your energy with your team mates, so that makes their attack even more powerful if everyone gives one to said team mate. The saving grace for that is there is a set up where you can turn off random encounters. I do this for exploring the dungeon, and grabbing chests. I use the battle system on mechanic strictly for grinding.

All in all, dispite how much of this game gets on my nerves, I still really like this game. I think it's mainly for the fact that I am bias towards 16bit style JRPGs. So I am going to recommend this game, but ONLY if you are a purist towards that style of game.

reviewText:
I got the game long time ago and had the review written up post gameplay. Sadly, I forgot to post it until now. Anyway, this will be a spoiler-free review of the game so that I can give people the idea of what I like and disliked about it.

Characters:  The characters have a plausible niche that feels like actual professions: One character is a botanist, another an inventor, and the last one is can read ancient scriptures due to living an archeologist life-style.  It is a bit refreshing to see such simple roles come to use during the game's narrative. Not just that, but the dialogue exchanged between the characters has a feel good tone to it.  In fact, even when you get a Game Over, the character dialogue exchange during the event put a smile to my face. It feels like the characters have life to them and you can tell that they've been best friends since childhood.

Gameplay:  So this is a love and hate for me. Let me go over the parts that I liked: The tutorial on how to battle was rather neat. I like the fact that the trainer gets you started in learning how the battle occurs. The 'gather' system is pretty unique in terms of being able to use spells and it is cool that you can pass it to your friends so that they can use their skill quickly. I like how you have an indication if your attack is good against enemies in the air or the ground. It is a nice change of pace for RPGs to know if you can strike in the air or not.  However, I will go over the gripes:  These are not intuitive in finding it.  Now, I think that may have been purposefully set so that you explore as the character, so I can overlook that. What I cannot overlook is the fact that it was not intuitive to know where or how the save point exists. There is a little pot somewhere that I found as the save point by chance. There was nothing that gave me the introduction to the save point or the concept of it. Again, I found that by chance, so that was a bit more annoying.

Gripes:  Cues/transitions. There are points where the game lacks it to where it gets annoying. Particular parts that I see are when people join the team, you don't get a cue when you are able to move again. One of the others are in various scenes, it feels like it ends abruptly. It's like you're expecting something to happen, but then the shift is '...Wait, that's it?' which I am not sure if it's because the transition needs to be slower or what. However, these are personal gripes.

Overall:  I enjoy the game and I recommend people to snag it. Give it a chance, you may like it.

reviewText: I like Pier Solar a lot, after logging for four hours so far. It's absolutely a game which seeks to capture a simpler time in RPG history--games like Lunar for the SegaCD, and Final Fantasy IV for the Super Nintendo come to mind. This early-'90s period is my favorite for the RPG genre, and I still regularly play my old favorites from 1989 - 1994 via emulation. It's great to have a new" game that hits the same notes
recommended: with some more panache in the graphics department.\n\nSpeaking of the new "HD" graphics

voteText: and stylistically a good match to the pixel art of the 16-bit graphics set of this game

I've gotten in the habbit of enabling the HD graphics for towns and then disabling them for dungeons because the pathways in dungeons are a lot harder to see with the paint-over versions of those backgrounds. This is even after the recent "pathway decluttering" that I see touted in the update notes.\n\nIn the case of both the 16-bit and "HD" graphics

column33: so I'm pretty sure I LOVE 'Pier Solar and the Great Architects.' I intend to play it all the way through to the end.\n\nIt's easy to nitpick a game like this and hold it up against games built by much larger teams with a lot more money. That's a testament to how well Pier Solar hits that bar

reviewText: I had high exepctations for this game, and it has failed to meet even the most basic of them.  The encounters are very unbalanced, the environment is used to conceal critical paths and information, and the puzzles are unintuitive.  The gameplay is depressingly linear, and uninteresting.  You basically do the same thing each battle, with very little variety.  The item progression is as expected from an RPG of this genre, but is still dissapointing.  There are far better games to spend your money on than this one.

reviewText: I am an old school RPG fan. I play games like Beyond the Beyond (which is pretty bad but manageable)  and the old school FFs and I can tell you this remake of an old Sega game is the worst piece of SH*T I have ever played in the RPG genre. The enemies pretty much stay the same though out the whole game, the pacing is crap, the story is uninteresting and the characters are terrible. The interface is clunky at best and you will spend almost all your money buying a few healing herbs from some vendor when each town has multiple vendors all at different prices which doesn't even matter because you will spend all your money anyway.\n\nThe game starts out with some promise but after the first town or two you get roped into a mysterious series of events which do not explain much. A drag through the middle of the game will leave you frustrated from long dungeons and uninterested about the points of the story probably because you will forget the reasons you were there in the first place. Seriously one of the most boring and repetitive pieces of garbage to be brought back to life and not worth the time or money. Free would be too expensive for this game simply because it is not worth the time you will put into it.

reviewText:
Less annoying than Millenium.

When I recommend a game, I typically recommend it based on how well it meets it's advertised hype.  After all, that's usually what convinces you to buy a game.  If the game doesn't live up to that hype, then you were cheated out of your money.

Pier Solar, while not a terrible game, doesn't live up to that hype.

The biggest hype of Pier Solar is that it is a port of a Genesis/Megadrive game.  Forget it, that has no factor here.  The graphics have all been updated so it looks like any other decent RPG Maker game.  The story never was up to snuff of genesis RPGs.  The FM based sound is the only thing that's left, but it's not on by default, so I guess even the developers didn't think that you would prefer the 16-bit version.

So the graphics are decent.  I don't need to explain that because there are screenshots, what you see is what you get.  But what's wrong with the story?  Well, I don't know entirely because I haven't played the whole thing, but after 6 hours I'm not sure if I want to play through the whole thing.  There has been zero real motivation.  The first chapter has been about finding a plant to heal the main's dad.  That's decent motivation for the characters, but I just met these people and have no reason to feel involved.  That part's over, so then they introduced a door that teleports you to a green room, we went to Pakistan, and now there are some furries.  That's neat, but there's nothing compelling about any of it.  Our heros are just exploring out of passing curiosity, just like me, and I don't think I have the stamina that they do.  Speaking of heros, I've spent 6 hours with the same 3 people and I don't dare try to spell their names without looking it up.  They are not compelling characters.  They are all young scientists who are good with weapons and magic.  If they could change weapon/element types, they might as well have been all the same character.  JRPG's are supposed to be deep and compelling, and that hasn't happened yet.

Everything else is pretty typical.  The battle system has a neat gather" feature which acts as a multiplier while fighting.  Required for certain spells.  That's the only thing that seems worth mentioning.  Battles are actually rather simplistic because you can't seem to share elemental powers between characters.  Eg: fire based weapons are only available for the fire based character.  The overworld also has the typical "get stuck on corners/can't tell what is or isn't a wall" features that you expect from RPG Maker games.

You can't expect Phantasy Star out of every retro tribute game
date: and WaterMelon made a lot of effort for a comparable 16-bit game.  Without the 16-bit hardware
hoursPlayed: Pier Solar is just another of the many fan made RPGs on Steam."
voteText: August 16, 2015

The writing is just, boring. It's a hard game to follow because you don't want too. The tropes are obnoxious with your superb male hero and that ONE mechanic nerd and that ONE gorgeous elven chick.
It's just...

No.

reviewText:
At first glance this seems like a throwback to the good old days of actually good JRPG's like Chrono Trigger, but finally on PC. Which this very well could be, but it's poorly optimised.

- The game freezes often
- Works for a few seconds then the FPS just drops dramatically to about 2 FPS, where it takes litterally 2 minutes just for the game to recognise that I hit confirm.

For a HD remake that is supposedly suppose to work on a Dreamcast. It's pretty sad that even modern PC's have trouble running this. I would say to give this game a pass until the Dev's fix it. At which point I may even come back to it and change the review if it actually works.

Makes me sad that a game with this much potential to be great doesn't work.

reviewText:
*The issues I'm about to talk about are valid regardless of my playtime, they may even get worse as the game goes on.

The HD BACKGROUND and text textures are nice.  But they did not redo any char models or item textures as far as I can tell.  The latter seem really muddy.

Also they seemingly did no work on the audio side of the game.  They recently added an option to lower SFX volume but it doesn't make up for the low quality of the SFX, just hides them.  Some sounds are incredibly loud for no reason, randomly, and will scare the crap out of you. Battle sounds are terrible, like nails scratching across a chalk board.

Also for any migraine or seizure sufferers.  The spell animations were not updated either.  So there is low effort screen flashing going on that might trigger your illness.  For example, the heal spell is a rapidly flashing white beam of light that spans vertically across the screen.

Honestly I could probably get into the game if I didn't feel like I was literally going to get a headache from playing it.

I'll edit the review in the future if I ever find the motivation or courage to finish.  Or if something drastically changes (like the screen flashing).

reviewText:
I love classic games mainly because I grew up on them, what I don't love is new games not learning from 20 years of game history and having to request features that for years were common sense additions to any game.


1. No pdf manual, no ingame explanation of things. I should not have to google or pay 50 bucks simply to understand the basics of the game, this is idiotic.
2. No way to speed up text and the text has an annoying delay inbetween every dialogue box.
3. No way to speed up things you have already been through.
4. The quickly annoying beep inbetween every dialogue box.
5. Why so much delay when finishing a battle? It seems that you made it so you hear the full song after a battle which gets old quick especially when the end of a battle takes longer than the battle itself.
6. Randomly getting coins or bars means little when you have no idea how much you got from a chest or what their value is.
7. What is with the 10 on items?(this is where basic tooltips, ingame explanations or a basic manual come in handy)

Now I am not bashing the whole game, but it does lack polish in areas. What it does great though is:

1. The script and characters are well done.
2. The game is beautiful.
3. The maps and the world are designed well.
4. The battle system while not unique works well.



Until the game comes with a basic pdf manual I will not recommend it, simple as that.

reviewText:
Too much dialogue at the beginning, not able to skip. For some who want mainly Role-Playing aspects, meh, fine. But you should really make it versatile to allow skipping so people who don't care about the story can skip it. Even being forced to read all of the dialogue, the controls are gimmicky and probably one of the weakest choices for assignment I've seen, paired with nothing but story line to go off of for early progression. You don't need a tutorial, just literally like one minor hint as to what to do would be enough, rather than just hoping to accidentally figure it out.

I am only interested in combat, so my review is based strictly on that. As of yet, I have experienced no combat in the first 15 minutes, which instantly makes me lose interest. There are two kinds of players, Role Players and Combatants, and some are both. Your game is too based on Role Playing that you lose 50% of your player base simply because you don't introduce combat early on. Many RPG games such as this begin the game with a Role Play scenario of a combat scene, giving both players a taste of what they're interested in. But, this game, you forego that and completely lose us Combatants by a slow and bland story line that we cannot skip to hope to get to combat sooner. I really want to see how combat plays out, but it honestly is not even worth getting there with how crappy the story is. If it was able to be skipped, and gave a quick 10-second hint at how to play, then it would be golden. About one day of work and you effectively increase your player population by double. But, obviously that isn't worth it, or the developer's didn't care enough and just wanted a Role Playing game.

TL;DR:
If you enjoy slow Role-Playing story-based games, you may be interested
If you enjoy combat in RPGs, save your money, but more importantly your time. 15 minutes into a game and no combat is too long. I feel like I just read the Terms and Conditions for a game before I even logged in.

15-minutes of play Rating: 3/10
Not worth swallowing the bile to go farther, save your money.

reviewText: As an old-school gamer back in the 8-bit/16-bit era, I never heard of this project until someone showed me their kickstarter  page in 2012 to put it onto modern consoles and devices. The presentation video blew me away with their excellent HD art and audio, let alone the amazing quality of the standard Mega Drive graphics and FM music too. It's a great first impression and, despite some nuisances in the game design, I enjoyed the time I had playing Pier Solar and the Great Architects.\n\nThe good stuff about the game is pretty clear from the store page that you've just glanced over. It has some fantastic pixel art, presented in 3 different formats: 16-bit, HD, and HD+. I would recommend either 16-bit or HD. HD+" looks just like HD but it smoothed over certain layers and doesn't seem to fit well with the other sprites. The animations are all well done for the most part too

column90: but ♥♥♥♥ this mini-game. You've been warned. Prepare for many long hours to finish this.\n\nWhen I began this game
column91: I was looking at giving it a 5/10
column93: I'm giving it a generous 7/10. I recommend it to old-school JRPG players that liked Lunar & Phantasy Star."

reviewText:
I was hoping to really enjoy this, but it's just so boring and it's a mess. I don't know how, but they were able to make the controls in a grid based RPG terrible. Why do I move to the left when I bump into the wall and end up going somewhere I don't want to. It's just frustrating and doesn't help in any way. Along with that, the combat is slow and unsatisfying with random advantage and disadvangates happening at the start of every battle (with a really loud freaking annoying sound effect.)

It's just not very good.

3/10
